'''Konstantinos Andravidiotis''' ({{lang-el|Κωνσταντίνος Ανδραβιδιώτης}}), also known with the surname '''Papadimitropoulos''' (Παπαδημητρόπουλος)<ref name=a>''Σύγχρονος Εγκυκλοπαίδεια Ελευθερουδάκη'', vol. 3, p. 94.</ref> or as "Captain Konstantis" (Καπετάν Κωνσταντής) was a chieftain of the [[Greek War of Independence]] from [[Andravida]].<ref>Encyclopedia ''Πάπυρος Λαρούς Μπριτάνικα'', 1989, vol. 9, p. 88.</ref>
==Biographical information== Andravidiotis was born in Andravida and had been active against the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman rule]] since the pre-revolutionary period. Due to his action, he was forced to resort to [[Zakynthos]], where he served in the British Army and became friends with [[Theodoros Kolokotronis]] and [[Charalambos Vilaetis]].<ref>Dimitrios Pan. Ekonomopoulos, ''Το χρονικό της Ανδραβίδας'', Andravida 1977, p. 43 - 44.</ref>
After the declaration of the [[Greek Revolution]] in [[Gastouni]], on 29 March 1821 Andravidiotis came under the command of [[Georgios Sisinis]] and was appointed head of the armed forces of [[Elis]], while he forced the local Ottoman forces to take refuge in the castle of [[Chlemoutsi]]. Then, he participated with other chieftains and notables to the revolutionary congress of [[Pyrgos, Elis|Pyrgos]] where the action against the Albanians of Lala was decided.<ref>Ekonomopoulos , 1977, p. 44.</ref> During the revolution, he took part in several battles including the [[Battle of Lala]], the battle in Pousi, in Andravida, in Gastouni, in Patras, in Santameri and in Portes.<ref>Ekonomopoulos, 1977, σ. 45 - 46.</ref> In [[1825]] he became chiliarch.<ref name=a/>
With the creation of the independent Greek state, Andravidiotis remained in the army and was employed, among others, in 1831 along with Diakos and Koumaniotis in the pursuit of an armed group that operated in Elis, while in 1835 he took over the oursuit against the Chondrogiannis robber clan.<ref>Ekonomopoulos, 1977, σ. 54 - 56.</ref> In July 1847 he became major in the [[Royal Phalanx]]<ref>Ekonomopoulos, 1977, σ. 56 - 57.</ref> ranked in the 4th class among majors.<ref name=a/> After his retirement, he became mayor of Myrtoudion. He died in 1856. From his marriage, he had four daughters and three sons.<ref>Ekonomopoulos, 1977, σ. 57.</ref>
